Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: GOUVERNANCE, SÉCURITÉ ET ÉTAT DE DROIT
Outcome: Des institutions légitimes et redevables garantissent l’État de droit, la bonne gouvernance et le respect des droits humains
Output: Formulation proposée Produit 1.4. La décentralisation est promue et l'accès aux services publics sont renforcés pour fournir des services de manière transparente, centrée sur les personnes, efficiente et efficace
Sub-Output: Renforcement de l'enregistrement universel des naissances et de l'etat civil dans les zones d'acces difficiles en Haiti .
Description: Le projet vise a renforcer les institutions de l'etat civil dans le departement des Nippes en vue de les permettre d''enregistrer les naissances dans les zones rurales et reculees .
Agencies: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
Contributing partners: The US Government Department of State's Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration, UNHCR Global Resources
Implementation partners: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
SDG Targets: 16.9 By 2030, provide legal identity for all, including birth registration.
Geography: Arnaud, Petit Trou de Nippes, Nippes, Haiti, Plaisance du Sud
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative:
Le Parlement haïtien a ratifié la Convention de 1954 relative au statut des personnes apatrides et la Convention de 1961 sur la réduction des cas d’apatridie et le Gouvernement a déposé les instruments d’adhésion aux deux instruments en septembre 2018.
Au Segment de haut niveau sur l’apatridie tenu à Genève en octobre 2019, le Gouvernement a pris les trois engagements suivants : (1) simplifier et améliorer l’accès à l’enregistrement des naissances dans les zones rurales et d’accès difficile ; (2) poursuivre la réforme de l’état civil lancée en 2005 ; et (3) harmoniser la législation sur la nationalité. En novembre 2019, le Gouvernement a aussi publié un arrêté accordant un délai de 5 ans aux personnes non enregistrées pour régulariser leur état civil. 
Dans ce contexte et suite au tremblement de terre du 14 aout 2021 ayant ravagé la région Sud du pays, le HCR s’est engagé à appuyer les institutions nationales de l’état civil à répondre au sérieux problème de documentation civile auquel la population de cette région est confrontée. Sur la base des consultations avec le ministère de la Justice et de la Sécurité Publique et la Direction des Archives Nationales d’Haiti (ANH), et d’une évaluation des besoins menée par l’Initiative Citoyenne pour les Droits de l’Homme (ICDH) en 2022, le besoin d’appuyer les bureaux d’état civil dans le département des Nippes a été identifié.
Ce projet, mis en œuvre par le HCR en partenariat avec le partenaire local ICDH, est conçu en vue d’appuyer le Gouvernement haïtien, dans la concrétisation des engagements pris au Segment de haut niveau sur l’apatridie et en lien avec la Campagne Globale du HCR pour mettre fin à l’apatridie et le Plan d’Action du Brésil. Cette initiative fait suite à un projet du même genre qui a été mis en œuvre en 2022. La population cible inclut les groupes suivants : (i) Les Haïtiens ou personnes d’origine haïtienne déportées d’un pays tiers vers Haiti en 2021 et en 2022 à risque d’apatridie ; (ii) les personnes déplacées internes qui ont perdu leur document d’état civil pendant le tremblement de terre du 14 aout 2021 et les autres aléas naturels qui ont affecté le département au cours des années antérieures, et (iii) les personnes non enregistrées et les nouveaux nés.
Les activités suivantes ont été mises en œuvre : 
a)      Renforcement de capacité de la contrepartie nationale et des acteurs de la société civile sur les questions liées à l’état civil, la législation nationale et les procédures d’enregistrement de naissance.b)      Activités de sensibilisation sur l’importance de la documentation civile et l’enregistrement des naissances c)      Appui aux bureaux d’état civil dans l’enregistrement des naissances à travers la fourniture d’équipements, de mobiliers et la mise à disposition de matériels d’enregistrement tels que les formulaires d’enregistrement de naissance et les registres.d)      Réalisation de campagnes mobiles d’enregistrement de naissances dans les zones rurales éloignées et d’accès difficile.e)      Appui au processus de numérisation des actes d’état civil par la donation d’équipements informatiques à la Direction des Archives Nationales d’Haiti (ANH).

Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind
Outcome: National governments and regional institutions use relevant data to design and adopt laws and policies to eliminate discrimination, address structural inequalities and ensure the advancement of those left furthest behind

Sub-Output: JAM: Raised awareness, enhanced capacities and advanced social science knowledge production to reduce inequalities, address different forms of discrimination and ethical risks, and foster gender equality.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,10.2 By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.,10.3 Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.,17.6 Enhance North-South, South-South and triangular regional and international cooperation on and access to science, technology and innovation and enhance knowledge sharing on mutually agreed terms, including through improved coordination among existing mechanisms, in particular at the United Nations level, and through a global technology facilitation mechanism.
SDG Goals: 5 Gender Equality, 10 Reduced Inequalities, 17 Partnerships for the Goals
Geography: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Lucia, Barbados, Bahamas, Cayman Islands, Trinidad and Tobago, Curaçao, Virgin Islands, British, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Suriname, Grenada, Dominica, Jamaica

Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way

2024 Narrative: -Conducted mentoring  gender equality training with Sheroes Alumni in collaboration with IGDS-RCO- Launch and dissemination of the 7th Module of Training Manual for Gender Equality, Advocacy and Development with a focus on LNOB (gender responsive knowledge product).- In 2024 the Sheroes Alumni Network was launched, who then helped design activities on gender biases in AI and 16 Days of Activism.- Additionally, work was expanded on gender  AI, looking at the impact of tech-facilitated GBV in the region through the development of a regional survey targeting women and following with a regional event within the framework of Human Rights Day, over 60 participants.- Dissemination of Training Manual for Disability Inclusion.- Drafting of Knowledge Series on Disability Inclusion in the Caribbean (knowledge product), bringing together social science knowledge to advance more inclusive Caribbean societies.- Ensured Caribbean representation at UNESCO Forum Against Racism and Discrimination, counting on participatio of Minister Grange at Ministerial High-Level Panel.- Organization of webinars to raise awareness on ethical and human-centered AI, reaching over 200 people.- Launch of Caribbean AI Policy Roadmap, including a consultative process reaching 1000 stakeholders.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Peace, Safety, Justice, and the Rule of Law
Outcome: Regional and national laws, policies, systems, and institutions improve access to justice and promote peace, social cohesion, and security
Output: MSDCF 7.1: Institutional capacity strengthened to reduce gender-based violence, violence against women and children and/or abuse
Sub-Output: JAM: [Spotlight Outcome 5] Quality, disaggregated and globally comparable data on different forms of violence against women and children, including intimate partner violence, girl-child sexual abuse, and discrimination, collected, analysed and used in line with international standards to inform laws, policies and programmes
Agencies: UN Women, United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: Jamaica Planning Institute, Jamaica Statistical Institute
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
QCPR function: Data Collection and Analysis, Capacity Development/Technical Assistance, Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/ women’s empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: Under Outcome 5, the Spotlight Initiative (SI) supported Jamaica’s efforts to collect, manage and disseminate globally comparable data on the prevalence of VAWG through concerted training and skill-building activities that enhanced the capacity of 43 officers in the national statistical system to produce and disseminate data on family violence. Additionally, 12 civil society organizations (CSOs) participated in an information-sharing session that allowed for an overview of the support services available to vulnerable and marginalized populations, the processes used in collecting data from women who use these services and how data is managed, analyzed, and utilized in programme planning and improvement. The “National Study on the Economic Costs of Violence Against Women and Girls in Jamaica” was undertaken in recognition of the fact that violence imposes costs on individuals (i.e., victims and their families) as well as the country. The study, which was well received by the Government of Jamaica, estimates the cost of VAWG and aids in understanding the severity of the costs and the impacts on the national income so that appropriate investments can be made to lessen, if not eradicate, the incidence of VAWG. The report also establishes a comprehensive economic costing model for Jamaica to estimate the cost of VAWG using country-level data and parameters.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Equality, Well-Being and Leaving No One Behind

Description: Phase 1 - Improved policy coherence at the national level in the Eastern Caribbean on the different forms of human mobility (migration, displacement and planned relocation) in contexts of disasters and climate change ; Phase 2 - Promoting a human security approach to disaster displacement, environmental migration and disaster risk reduction in the Caribbean Region.
Contributing partners: United Nations Trust Fund for Human Security
Implementation partners: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
SDG Targets: 10.7 Facilitate orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility of people, including through the implementation of planned and well-managed migration policies.
Geography: Virgin Islands, British, Saint Lucia, Grenada, Dominica, Anguilla (United Kingdom), Antigua and Barbuda, Montserrat, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines
Gender marker: 1 - Contributes to gender equality/women’s empowerment in a limited way
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: In 2022 IOM published a report on planned relocation policies and processes in the Caribbean: https://kmhub.iom.int/en/virtual-library/finding-safer-ground-planned-relocation-policies-and-processes-caribbean
2023 Narrative: Developed the Environmental Migration, Disaster, Displacement and Human Security Policy Assessment Tool. Produced 9 Assessment reports from the application of the assessment tool. Identified best practices on protection of persons crossing borders due to disasters, environmental degradation and climate change in the Eastern Caribbean. Developed a cross-border evacuation protocol for countries of the Eastern Caribbean in the context of disasters. Facilitated a Ministerial Declaration on Migration, Environment and Climate Change - A first for the OECS region.Presented at the OECS Immigration Council of Ministers Meeting on 13 April 2023 in Dominica.
2024 Narrative: Focused on promoting the resources developed under Phase 1 in 2023 (see 2023 narrative report); achieved greater working synergy with CDEMA and has made significant progress towards the inclusion of human mobility in CDEMA's CDM Strategy and Country Work Programmes (CWPs) of Participating States. "There has been an enhanced awareness of the value of the human security approach in addressing issues relating to human mobility, climate change, and disasters in the Caribbean Region. Further, the work being done has contributed to regional agencies, national organizations, and communities having enhanced systems and capacities for disaster risk management that support adaptation to the current and long-term effects of climate change and environmental. The Joint Programme has successfully elevated the consideration of the human security approach at the highest level in the region through the OECS Ministerial Declaration on Migration, Environment, and Climate Change. Regional agencies and national governments now have access new resources to support the management of human mobility in the context of disasters. Moreover, through local partnerships, the programme has managed to raise awareness among youths on human security in disaster preparedness.
